Manx: A song composed when harvest was over and the cold of winter had come.
English: A song composed when harvest was over and the cold of winter had come.
Diplomatic: A song composed when harvest was over and the cold of winter had come

English: The beautiful summer has gone again,
The autumn is also gone,

Manx: Ta çhiass ny greiney ersooyl neesht
English: The heat of the sun has gone too,
Diplomatic: Ta chass ny ghrainey ersooyl neesht

English: And cold comes behind it.
The stormy winter is now around,
With cold snow and ice,

Manx: Cha vell e throme myr ve un cheayrt,
English: It is not heavy as it once was,
Diplomatic: Cha vell e throme myr ve un cheayrt

Manx: Roïe ayns my vea ayns shoh.
English: Before in my life here.
Diplomatic: Roie ayns my vea ayns shoh

English: The birds that were making music,

Manx: Ta ersooyl er gys yn chrow,
English: Are gone to the bush,
Diplomatic: T’er sooyl er gys yn chrow

Manx: Gyn veg agh robbin noon as noal,
English: With none but the robin to and fro,
Diplomatic: Gyn veg agh Rovin noon as noall

English: Coming around a house to warm.
Notes: dy çhiow— lention would be expected here, but see also Kelly; dy çhiow.

Manx: Ta’n gheay vooar sheidey er yn mooir,
English: The great wind blows on the sea,
Diplomatic: T’an gheay wooar sheidey er yn muir

English: And angry waves race,

Manx: As eeanlee nagh vel buinn ny cuirr,
English: And birds that neither reap nor sow,
Diplomatic: As yeenlee nagh vell buin ny quir

English: Now sit in the trees.

Manx: Cha vel eer fiogit, duillag hene,
English: Not even shrivelled, even a leaf,
Diplomatic: Cha vell eer ffgyt dhullag hene

English: They are driven before the wind,

Manx: Ga nagh vel guiy feie çheet lesh sheean,
English: Although no wild goose comes with noise,
Diplomatic: Gha nagh vell geye feaih cheet lesh sheeyn

English: Or many wild ducks.

Manx: Ta’n feeagh sy rhennagh shassoo nish,
English: The raven in the bracken stands now,
Diplomatic: T’an feeagh sy rennagh shassoo nish

English: And croaks as he always has,

Manx: As gaccan myr lesh skian brisht,
English: And complains as if with a broken wing,
Diplomatic: As gagnan myr lesh skainy brish

English: On the cold side of the mountain.

Manx: Ny magheyryn ta jiarg as creen,
English: The fields that are red and withered,
Diplomatic: Ny magheyryn ta jairg as chreen

English: Not much grass for for the livestock,

Manx: Ny conney da ny kirree hene,
English: Or heather for even for the sheep,
Diplomatic: Ny conney da ny keerree hene

English: But expecting it to grow.

Manx: Yn thalloo hene ta croi as feeayr,
English: The land itself that is hard and cold,
Diplomatic: Yn thalloo hene ta croi as feeayr

English: The pools that are like glass,
Diplomatic: Ny phuyll ta gholl rish ghless

Manx: Lesh rio as geay te feayr dy liooar,
English: With ice and wind it is cold enough,
Diplomatic: Lesh rio as gheay te feayr dy lhioor

English: But we must make do with it.
Although cold is not pleasurable,
For those that ‘run in age’,

Manx: Ny-yeih ta’n berçhagh as yn boght,
English: Nevertheless, the richman and the poorman,
Diplomatic: Ny-yeih t’an berchagh as yn boght

English: Are served alike.

Manx: Tra bee yn geurey feayr ersooyl,
English: When the cold winter will be gone,
Diplomatic: Tra bee yn geurey feayr ersooyl

English: The sun having got heat,

Manx: Eisht vees e taitnyssagh dy hooyl
English: Then it will be pleasurable to walk
Diplomatic: Esht ves e taitnysagh dy chooyl

English: When the grass reappears.
Diplomatic: Tra hig yn faiyr er rash.

English: Faragher
56 Blackwell Colliery,
Derbyshire, England.
